headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Expedia, Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will turn the call over to Mr. Alan Pickerill, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahe
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Expedia, Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will turn the call over to Mr. Alan Pickerill, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Expedia, Inc.'s Financial Results Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter and Full Year Ended December 31, 2010. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mic
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Expedia, Inc.'s Financial Results Conference Call for the Fourth Quarter and Full Year Ended December 31, 2010. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Michael Adler, our CFO.
The following discussion, including responses to your questions, reflects management's views as of today, February 10, 2011, only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise this information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You'll find reconciliations of non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today in our earnings release, which is posted on the company's IR website at expediainc.com/ir. I encourage you to periodically visit our IR site for important content, including today's earnings release and our updated investor presentation.
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense, and technology and content expense, excludes stock-based compensation. And all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2009.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan, and thanks to everyone for joining us this afternoon. Overall 2010 was a solid year with room night growth of 40%, air ticket growth of 11% and operating income before amortization, or OIBA growth of 9%. We would've made our low double-digit
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan, and thanks to everyone for joining us this afternoon. Overall 2010 was a solid year with room night growth of 40%, air ticket growth of 11% and operating income before amortization, or OIBA growth of 9%. We would've made our low double-digit OIBA growth target excluding certain items that Mike will discuss later. 
Adjusted earnings per share grew a robust 24% on an improved operating performance held by nearly $500 million of share repurchases.  While Mike will cover the Q4 financial results in a bit more detail, I'd like to cover some of our strategic focus areas.
We believe that we've just touched a surface and have significant potential ahead of us on product improvements, resulting from our technology investments. For example, we're seeing great results at Hotels.com, which completed its but platform migration in roughly a year ago, and has executed quite effectively, driving commercial improvements at substantially higher room night growth in both the U.S. and Europe compared to just have a year ago.
January trends are even better with Hotels.com room night growth in the 30% range, so we're very encouraged by their progress and execution.
Our Expedia brand posted mixed results in the quarter and overall, grew revenue at roughly the same rate as the third quarter. We've just brought in a new President for the division, Scott please was read-only the COO of Skype and started with us at the beginning of the year. 
We are in the midst of significant platform work with Expedia brand, which picks up again to lead to convert an improvement in roughly six to nine months, similar to the conversion improvements that we've already seen at Hotels.com subsequent to their platform work.
We've got a good playbook, and believe that this team could effectively execute that playbook for Expedia. And as we improve our product, we continue to see strong results from our loyalty program at Hotels.com, and are investing in a new program at Expedia. 
Hotels.com Welcome Aboard is no well over 2 million members, and we've found that these numbers not only spend more with us but they also come to us through cheaper marketing channels than our other customers. Expedia.com has now soft launched its new loyalty program, exceed Aurora, which allows us to give our members more points, including points for air travel.
We view these investments as building both around our bread to customers in an ever more competitive environment.
Now all of our brands also have significant efforts underway in social, media and mobile, as these two titles are exploding and represent significant long-term opportunity for. 
Mobile bookings are growing very past across our brands, and extremely short booking window on these transactions, a very hard percentage of which are same-day bookings suggest to us that they are likely incremental.
We acquired Mobiata, a proven success story in Q4 to accelerate our efforts in mobile. Mobiata is best known for its flight status application, FlightTrack, a top iPhone App for the last two years, and we've just last week, announced the acquisition of Evertrail. Evertrail will be part of TripAdvisor and has developed a GPS enabled publishing platform to create outdoor tour and city guides for mobile devices. The technology will come TripAdvisor's millions of traveler reviews and opinions, and enrich the quality of information our consumers can access from there smart phones.
TripAdvisor's itself had a great year with annual third-party revenue growth of 48% and growth in the international business in excess of 100 percent. Ever to continue in insert expansion and a new products. The hotel listings product now boasts nearly 25,000 hotel properties, and we've seen strong renewal rates.
We're finding that a good number of these hotel customers are smaller, independent boutique properties in Europe who love the product and nearly 1/3 of whom don't have an existing relationship with an OTA. In social media, TripAdvisor recently launched its instant resolution efforts in Facebook and has seen tremendous results with recently moving into the number two spots among companies using personalization with Facebook just behind.
And TripAdvisor leading the way, we believe that over time, or an advertising medium business will reach $1 billion in revenue. 
Now looking ahead, our focus remains squarely on building the best travel products and experiences for travelers all over the world, and tapping into the incredibly explosive new channels such as mobile and social media, and into promising regions such as Asia Pacific and Latin America. We're very encouraged by our early results and are confident that they can earn substantial returns in these opportunities, and will not pullback in these investments to any short-term financial hit that we may see as a result of any near-term events.
I'm happy to cover more details on these initiatives when we get to Q&A. But for now, let me pass it on to Mike.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's Dara. Q4 was a solid finish to a good here I'll be applied on the bottom line than we had planned. We were pleased with the revenue growth of 16% in the quarter. Q4 OIBA growth of 7%, included an aggregate $10 million for increased occupancy tax se
componenttext:
That's Dara. Q4 was a solid finish to a good here I'll be applied on the bottom line than we had planned. We were pleased with the revenue growth of 16% in the quarter. Q4 OIBA growth of 7%, included an aggregate $10 million for increased occupancy tax settlement reserves and accruals, and the net impact of certain accounting adjustments. 
In addition, we think that the winter storms affected OIBA by around $5 million for the quarter. Without these items, we would've easily achieved our low double-digit OIBA growth target for the year.
We were also pleased to see revenue margins high year-on-year for the first time since we took the significant consumer fee actions in 2009. And once again, we generated substantial free cash flow, $622 million for the year.
From a brand perspective, we saw a strong performance from Hotels.com whose Q4 revenue growth accelerated sharply from Q3 as a result of faster room night growth.  And it's especially to see the revenue growth for Hotels.com accelerate in each of North America, Europe and APAC simultaneously. 
TripAdvisor continues to post strong results, including third-party international revenue growth over 80% for the quarter. And even with tougher comps, Egencia continued its excellent performance with gross bookings growth of 27% and revenue growth of 33%, as our Corporate Travel brand outshines competitors in helping clients move their travel bookings online, and to better manage their travel spend.
From a product perspective, hotel room nights in Q4 grew faster than in Q3 at 15% year-on-year continuing the long-term trend of taking share in the lodging market. Both domestic and international grew a healthy clip and at rate similar to last quarter. Volume was modestly impacted by the severe weather conditions experienced in Q4. Our ADRs were up 2% for the quarter with flat revenue per room night.
In air, ticket growth was 6% year-over-year with a 9% increase in revenue per ticket. In Q4, we accelerated revenue recognition on our merchant air product to the book to date, which accounted for roughly 2/3 of the improvement per ticket. This of course, is a one-time impact, so we do not expect to see similar revenue per ticket growth looking forward.
Since the beginning of the year, we're pleased to have signed three new multi-year supply agreements with U.S. Airways and Westjet. On the expense side, we accelerated the recognition of certain credit card fee payments. And these, along with some other adjustments, drove the deleverage in cost of revenue in the quarter. 
In fact, without these adjustments, cost of revenue would've grown slower than revenue for the quarter and for the full year. I would also note that the customer operations component of cost of revenue grew just 7% in the quarter, showing good leverage.
As far as our financial expectations are concerned, we're expecting mid-single-digit OIBA growth for full year 2011. We expect healthy hotel room night growth again, but expect air to be challenged by higher average ticket prices and inventory availability.
Keep in mind our forecast for 2011 includes significant investments, continuing projects of which we began in 2010, as well as new investments beginning in Q1. These investments across technology and marketing are intended to improve our competitive standing and position as well for long-term sustainable growth, and include: Platform work on Expedia, expansion in APAC and Latin Am, new platforms like social and mobile, and new product offerings like loyalty programs and international . As a result, for the year, we're targeting leverage and cost of revenue and G&A but expect deleverage in selling and marketing and tech and content.
Q1 is seasonally our lowest revenue quarter of the year. With the investments we're making and other near-term headwinds, we expect OIBA in Q1 to be flat-to-down. More broadly, we're expecting stronger OIBA growth in the second half of the year, compared to the growth we'll see in the first half.
As usual, our financial expectations are based on current foreign exchange rates, and any rate fluctuations could have an impact on our actual results. Our strategic focus has never been better. We're working very hard to make the right investments for the long-term growth of the business while still delivering solid near-term results.
We are extremely energized by the opportunities and challenges we have in front of us. With that, let's turn to questions. Operator, would you please remind listeners how to ask a question?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ingrid Chung from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Ingrid Chung from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: As far as the, how much of TripAdvisor's traffic coming from Google organic results, that's something that for competitive reasons, we're not going to talk about. Suffice it to say that the Google channel both paid and organic is a very significant channe
componenttext: As far as the, how much of TripAdvisor's traffic coming from Google organic results, that's something that for competitive reasons, we're not going to talk about. Suffice it to say that the Google channel both paid and organic is a very significant channel for TripAdvisor. The TripAdvisor team is -- the TripAdvisor content is a terrific content and the rebuke of content continues to grow and continues to be fresh. So it shows a very high and organic results. And obviously, the TripAdvisor SEM team is also high-performing team. So Google is a very big and important channel for TripAdvisor, and we'll remain a large channel for them. As far as the effect, the specific effect of Google places, the actual removal of links on places really has not had that significant in effect on TripAdvisor at all. The traffic that we got, or get from places in general, is pretty small relative to our overall traffic. What effect us more in Google favoring places its own internal results, so to speak, over organic results. So to the extent that Google is favoring its own results places, and automatically putting them on top of organic results which are call it, third-party results as we've seen, that which is third-party results down. We don't think it's a good consumer experience, because clearly, consumers do like to look at reviews et cetera. But that's really the traffic driver, it's not traffic through places but it's traffic through the SCO links that's very important for TripAdvisor. Even with all that, you can definitely see TripAdvisor's revenue growth is still very, very healthy, and we expect quick growth in 2011 to be well in excess of 20% plus. And we expect to provide to revenue growth to continue. TripAdvisor's really diversified its source of revenue to both in the U.S. but especially internationally. It's international growth is incredibly strong. We are in 27-plus countries and expanding on a monthly basis. And also, we have made very significant investments in building the mobile channel wherein in any country we're on the ground, we also include mobile side. We just released an iPad application et cetera. And mobile is turning out to be a very significant and quickly growing channel for TripAdvisor and social as well, our instant personalization efforts with Facebook are very interesting, and we are increasing the number of people who are personalized on Facebook at a rapid rate which I think really differentiates TripAdvisor. TripAdvisor used to be just about the wisdom of the crowds. And we're transforming TripAdvisor from not just being the wisdom of the crowds but to also be the wisdom of the crowds and your best friends, and knowing where your friends have been and understanding what advice can get from them. So these investments that we made for two, three years. We think we are very well-positioned and we see the Google channel growing healthily. And we see these other new channels growing even faster.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Naved Kahn from Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Naved Kahn from Jefferies & Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: One question on the 30% kind of growth that you mentioned on the hotel side in January. Is there something different that your doing now versus just a quarter and to this acceleration, or is it just a ramp-up of effort?
componenttext: One question on the 30% kind of growth that you mentioned on the hotel side in January. Is there something different that your doing now versus just a quarter and to this acceleration, or is it just a ramp-up of effort?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: It really has to do with the platform migration that we've talked about, and it's the same thing that essentially, Expedia is going through. Hotels.com in 2009, we reinvested the platform, we combined the European platform and the U.S. platform, and that
componenttext: It really has to do with the platform migration that we've talked about, and it's the same thing that essentially, Expedia is going through. Hotels.com in 2009, we reinvested the platform, we combined the European platform and the U.S. platform, and that platform work was really completed in Q1 of 2010. Once we improve the platform and completed our work, we were able to engage in significantly accelerated work on the hotel path on the various stages to innovate and bring in new feature sets, which increases conversions for Hotels.com. And it's kind of a sequential methodology. You come out with a new feature, you test it. If it works, you roll it out, if it doesn't work, you pull it back. So it's really, the optimization, I'd say, the great work that the Hotels.com team has done on site optimization, which is gone throughout 2010 and has added up on top of its health. So when we look at Hotels.com's growth rate in 2010, the first half was not so good, but the second half got better. And in 2011, it's really off to a roaring start. And it's really that playbook that I was talking about for Expedia. The Expedia platform is more complex. It has more lines of business, so to speak. But we've seen at work for Hotels.com and there's no reason why it can't work for Expedia as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, what kind of impact did you see in January from the ticketing issue with American Airlines?
componenttext: And then secondly, what kind of impact did you see in January from the ticketing issue with American Airlines?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're still trying to work that out, and I'm not going to specifically talk about partner kind of relationships and their allies. Obviously, American on Airlines content on Expedia, we think having maximum content, open content in general on OTAs and on a
componenttext: We're still trying to work that out, and I'm not going to specifically talk about partner kind of relationships and their allies. Obviously, American on Airlines content on Expedia, we think having maximum content, open content in general on OTAs and on a broad basis on the Internet is great for customers. It's great for us. We think it's good for Americans. But we've got to work with the American on terms that works for us, and are fair to our customers, so to speak. So while certainly, Americans not be on the site, will have some short-term impact on our financial results. We still have a great air product. We've got a dynamite Hotel product and we have a business that's very, very diversified, the media streams, the hotel' streams and the international revenue coming in. so certainly not a position that we want to be in from a long-term basis, but this it's a bump in the roads. And we hope that they can come to terms with American that satisfies both sides.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mark Mahaney with Citigroup.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, especially, about the mobile app company that you acquired. And you indicated that it accounts for mobile traffic accounts for 4% of Expedia traffic, and bookings of about 600 per share year-over-year. So how similar, or different d
componenttext: A couple of questions, especially, about the mobile app company that you acquired. And you indicated that it accounts for mobile traffic accounts for 4% of Expedia traffic, and bookings of about 600 per share year-over-year. So how similar, or different do you think is the monetization rate of traffic on mobile versus regular traffic? And how material can mobile become? I just want to get your sense.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, honestly, I think it's a pretty speculative question, and my guess is as good as anyone else's. We don't think that there's any reason why mobile traffic can convert or shouldn't convert, as well as web traffic. Today on Expedia for example,
componenttext: Yes, I think, honestly, I think it's a pretty speculative question, and my guess is as good as anyone else's. We don't think that there's any reason why mobile traffic can convert or shouldn't convert, as well as web traffic. Today on Expedia for example, mobile traffic does convert at lower rates as our site. But we think that we can close the gap, so to speak, and we can close the gap quickly. And that to some extent, is a pretty significant reason why we've brought Mobiata in-house. It's a small team that thinks mobile but thinks differently and already the kind of work that they're doing with Expedia team is incredibly encouraging as far as radically, radically improving the quality of our mobile product. So within in 2011, we expect to see those benefits. People are coming to the mobile side. And we think that to the extent that we can increase conversion to any place close to the overall stock conversion, this can be a channel that's growing even faster. If it's 4% of our -- if it's 4%, 5% of our traffic, I think it can get to 10-plus-percent of our traffic within the next 12 to 18 months easily, not only the U.S. but also abroad is right. But those are wild guesses. So we are very hopeful of the team coming in. we are working well together with them, and we think that it just jump-starts our efforts there, and hopefully, and it distinguishes our product above what else do you see in the market place.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hotels.com mobile is already converting at the same or better rates than it is on the website. And also, when we think of mobile, we also think of tablet and iPad et cetera and we're having very good early signs of success there as well. As Dara said, it
componenttext: Hotels.com mobile is already converting at the same or better rates than it is on the website. And also, when we think of mobile, we also think of tablet and iPad et cetera and we're having very good early signs of success there as well. As Dara said, it remains to be seen just how big it can be but we are very encouraged.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Mike, can you give a sense of -- you talked about investment and it are that in particular, Asia Pacific, the what kind of investments do you think you need to make the fuel growth for the Asian markets, and how long do you expect to be in investment
componenttext: And Mike, can you give a sense of -- you talked about investment and it are that in particular, Asia Pacific, the what kind of investments do you think you need to make the fuel growth for the Asian markets, and how long do you expect to be in investment mode?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: In Asia Pacific, we talked about that in a bit on our last call. We're going to be expanding the Expedia points-of-sale in Hotels.com points-of-sale in the region. We're also adding a lot more feed on the ground, particularly in our PSG market management
componenttext: In Asia Pacific, we talked about that in a bit on our last call. We're going to be expanding the Expedia points-of-sale in Hotels.com points-of-sale in the region. We're also adding a lot more feed on the ground, particularly in our PSG market management organization. And it's something where we think that in 2011, the investment can really ramp us up by much more successful 2012. I can't really predict right now how long we're going to be in investment mode. But I think as we go through 2011 and evaluate the returns that we're getting, we'll keep you guys posted.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just to give you a little bit more color on Asia and investments there, the Hotels.com has a broad basis in Asia and has the kind of breath of coverage that we wanted to have. So for Hotels.com, it's a matter of optimizing the site, improving the cont
componenttext: And just to give you a little bit more color on Asia and investments there, the Hotels.com has a broad basis in Asia and has the kind of breath of coverage that we wanted to have. So for Hotels.com, it's a matter of optimizing the site, improving the contents, investing in marketing and expanding. And we're seeing growth rates actually in 2011 that are accelerating over what we saw in 2010. Usually, in these markets, they get bigger, they kind of slowdown, but here's the actual acceleration with Hotels.com. Some of this has to do with platform from investment that we talked about previously. Expedia's exposure in Asia Pacific is a bit more concentrated. It's mostly in Australia, Japan and India. And what you will see with Expedia in 2011 is a significant acceleration, and the points-of-sale that we actually launched. We launched in Singapore and expect us to launch in anywhere between five to seven, or eight new countries, depending on our technology launch schedule in 2011. So we're pretty excited about that. And then TripAdvisor's very broad coverage in Asia in general, but we do continue to invest very aggressively in the Chinese market. That cushion was essentially TripAdvisor for China already has the greatest number of reviews in the Chinese markets and growing very quickly. Cushion is the number two medi-search player there. And we're investing in excess of $10 million in losses a year there, but the Chinese market is worth it. It's a giant market. These sites are top 10 sites, and we think that near-term investment is going to pay off long term in a big way. And we think it puts us in a unique position. We don't think there's any other kind of global OTA out there, travel company out there that is building this kind of a position in China. We think it's going to pay off, and it's going to pay off pretty significantly.

So internationally, we felt less than we certainly felt it more in the U.S. Although again, quick growth for TripAdvisor, we think in 2011, it's going to be quite healthy. As far as the percentage of hotel bookings, you want to talk about that, Mike?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: Sure. It's not a number that we specifically disclose but a number of folks come in and buy a stand-alone air ticket, and then come back to buy a stand-alone hotel room is fairly low. And again, not a metric that we disclose.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the other side of that is certainly the Package business for us at Expedia is pretty an important driver of economics and hotel room nights. And to the extent that air inventory in the package path becomes less optimal than the hotel. Obviously th
componenttext: I think the other side of that is certainly the Package business for us at Expedia is pretty an important driver of economics and hotel room nights. And to the extent that air inventory in the package path becomes less optimal than the hotel. Obviously the hotel room nights added this package, out of the package path will slowdown, and we are seeing signs of that in January. But when it gets to stand-alone hotel room night growth at Expedia, which are at good double digit rates, those searchers tend to just come in and search for hotels and book hotels.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And how much of the emerging businesses in TripAdvisor contributing right now?
componenttext: And how much of the emerging businesses in TripAdvisor contributing right now?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: They're getting bigger and bigger. Again, we don't disclose financial specifically but what I was talking to Steve Copper, who's the CEO of TripAdvisor and he said in January, probably 25% of his traffic came from U.S. IPs. So 75% of the TripAdvisors traf
componenttext: They're getting bigger and bigger. Again, we don't disclose financial specifically but what I was talking to Steve Copper, who's the CEO of TripAdvisor and he said in January, probably 25% of his traffic came from U.S. IPs. So 75% of the TripAdvisors traffic now is coming from non-U.S. IPs. Obviously, the non-U.S. business is younger. It doesn't monetize as well. But it's a pretty extraordinary number, and it tells you about the long path that TripAdvisor has as far as growth goes. To give you an idea again of the growth and monetization, to Budweiser's revenue, 50-plus percent of TripAdvisor's revenue, well over 50% is the U.S. but so much of the traffic is not coming internationally. And we think as the gap between the two narrows, we have pretty extraordinary long-term revenue opportunity.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think every contract is different and there are certain partners -- we're certain open to working with partners on that basis. But every contract is unique. Some of our partners like to pay kind of flat fee for traffic. Some of them will pay different a
componenttext: I think every contract is different and there are certain partners -- we're certain open to working with partners on that basis. But every contract is unique. Some of our partners like to pay kind of flat fee for traffic. Some of them will pay different amounts based on international traffic coming in, and we have tested with certain contracts where partners might pay differently for traffic coming from a hub or non-hub city. The one thing that we have common in all the contracts, is we get paid a commission our partners, and we connect to the GDS and again, I think if Americans are willing to work with us the way that 300 other airliners are, we'll certainly be happy to work with then.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: And thus U.S. Airways, the choice seats, is that coming fully through the GDS, or how is that -- is that being handled as a fair class? How are you actually, logistically handling that?

componenttext: We had it that it's going to come through the GDS. And so that's how we think it's going to work, to the extent that they cant make it work through the GDS, we'll figure it out in a whole alternative way. But I think the point is Dan customer experience, right? We made a deal when U.S. Air, all their content is in. We want to be able to do retail toys seats for them. We'd rather get it through the GDS because that's a very easy way of getting content and presenting in them. That our anticipation for now.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Everman with Barclays Capital.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the marketing costs, it's a number of different things. There definitely is some CPC inflation that we're seeing across the business. I don't have kind of domestic versus international break out for you but I would say we're definitely seeing that, and
componenttext: On the marketing costs, it's a number of different things. There definitely is some CPC inflation that we're seeing across the business. I don't have kind of domestic versus international break out for you but I would say we're definitely seeing that, and we also are continuing to grow faster and expand in international markets where our marketing efficiency today is still lower than it is in the U.S., and that is part of the reason we're making the investments that we're making in the platform to drive conversion and try and get that more equivalent. So we are again, spending more on SEM. I think we've mentioned that on prior calls, that we've determined that that's an area of the market that there's further opportunities for us to take some more share in. On guidance, I'm going to restate what you said because I'm not sure what it was exactly consistent with what I said in my remarks. For Q1, we expect Q1 to be flat-to-down. We said that we expect to see the second half of the year grow faster than the first half of the year. And there are a number of things going on there. To a large degree, to really has to do with copying some of the investment that we started to make in the second half of 2010 and so we're having much more significant comps in the first half of 2011. It's our more typical pattern to hold technology and content spend flat from Q4 to Q1. This year, we're actually increasing it. So that will also make the comps a bit more difficult. In the second half of the year, we do believe that we'll start to see some of the conversion benefits on Expedia that Dara referred you earlier, and that will also help the business as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess a c could, could you tell us what percentage of your hotel revenues that are direct connect? And I assume it's pretty high, why can't that be the case, where the airlines as well? And could you also sort of I guess unrelated, tell us what the rent
componenttext: I guess a c could, could you tell us what percentage of your hotel revenues that are direct connect? And I assume it's pretty high, why can't that be the case, where the airlines as well? And could you also sort of I guess unrelated, tell us what the rental car companies supply and pricing, it's looked like and currently, looks like over the next several months we've.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. As far as a hotel to reconnect, the majority of our transactions come through, I guess what you'd call direct connect. They're really two, I think three scientists for photo connectivity that we used for hotel connectivity. One is we have a sy
componenttext: Sure, Mike. As far as a hotel to reconnect, the majority of our transactions come through, I guess what you'd call direct connect. They're really two, I think three scientists for photo connectivity that we used for hotel connectivity. One is we have a system called AR&I a where we connect into the major chain revenue systems electronically. We also have another system where we provide kind of an extra net signs for hotels called smaller independent hotels. And update their pricing inventory et cera. And then we also connect through the GDS. And those are the three areas. In general, our transactions to the AR&I kind of the extra nets electronic connectivity and through the extranet significantly exceed our transactions through the GDS. As far as why can't air be the same, I'd point you to a couple of factors. First of all, we built his systems over a number of years on the hotel side. The hotel business has 60-plus percent of our revenues and as a result, we are happy to allocate very significant capital to that side of our business, which is really providing the majority of our revenue. And when we built our Merchant Hotel product, there really wasn't a connectivity system that can get is what we want it, which is kind of instantaneous inventory pricing at the scale that we want. So really have to build it ourselves because there was a third-party offering it, the way that we want it, we might have picked up that third-party. We still use very as the parties help us with our connectivity in various ways. The other factor that I'd add is that in general, air bookings are much more complex at hotel bookings as far as getting a specific seat, a different pair classes, pricing is much more variable and if you want us to a hotel in Chicago comes at a pretty simple questions. If you want to fly from London to Chicago, there are literally tens of thousands of ways to get there, and that's much more complex question to ask. So building up, we think hotels direct connect, which we have, is not quite as large a channel just as building out air direct connect. And there are partners who build up their connect. They have this wonderful switches, terrific technology and great partners of ours called GDS. And the vast majority of our air partners are happy to work with us to GDS, and we think that long term, is a model that's worked and we think it's a model that will continue to work. As far as car side, the transaction growth in the quarter was healthy. There was some pricing improvements I'd say on kind of slowly improving capacity the industry. And what we're seeing for the quarter coming forward is that we do expect fleet capacity growth what you're hearing from car companies is that they're going to be fairly cautious on the capacity to go all become air capacity and the effect of oil prices etc. is going to have some effect on what we see our partners doing. So in general, we see growth bookings revenue on the car side growing but we think that revenue per unit, revenue per rental day is probably going to be a headwind in 2011 rather than detailed.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: When you say price improvement in the quarter just ended, do you mean that you're getting a lower price, and enterprise or the car rental companies getting a better price we've.
componenttext: When you say price improvement in the quarter just ended, do you mean that you're getting a lower price, and enterprise or the car rental companies getting a better price we've.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say in general, pricing has been stable top or can we have seen a mix shift from higher margin products so to speak to lower margin products in general. So that has been a headwind of the revenue side. But in general, pricing has been decent. But I th
componenttext: I'd say in general, pricing has been stable top or can we have seen a mix shift from higher margin products so to speak to lower margin products in general. So that has been a headwind of the revenue side. But in general, pricing has been decent. But I think we do expect some headwinds on car pricing going in to 2011.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then one final question getting back to the first. ITA, does that offer reasonable competitive product to the GDS?
componenttext: And then one final question getting back to the first. ITA, does that offer reasonable competitive product to the GDS?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: ITAA is the dominant pricing system, airline pricing system out there for third-party. So the GDS offer lots of services, airline hosting products and actually connectivity. They will allow us to book through tickets etc. agency tickets with our airline p
componenttext: ITAA is the dominant pricing system, airline pricing system out there for third-party. So the GDS offer lots of services, airline hosting products and actually connectivity. They will allow us to book through tickets etc. agency tickets with our airline partners and airlines can load their fairs at that or. IT, at this point, provides just third-party pricing. So that if, let's say, I talked about flying from London to Chicago, I Table five different itineraries and try to price the message area out there similar to an internal product that we have called BFS. We know that IT is trying to develop GDS hosting like functionality. But at least we haven't seen that in the market get.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Sandler with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Sandler with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Agenda call a bit late but I just had two questions. These may be repetitive but first on TripAdvisor, the margin decline that you saw in TripAdvisor, is that solely due to the kind of high margin revenue coming out from your getting traffic that you're g
componenttext: Agenda call a bit late but I just had two questions. These may be repetitive but first on TripAdvisor, the margin decline that you saw in TripAdvisor, is that solely due to the kind of high margin revenue coming out from your getting traffic that you're getting from Google? And do we think about the margin in this business year-over-year, should we see the same kind of decline until we recalled this quarter next year? Or are there variable cost that you can cut in TripAdvisor business to kind of get your margins back up? Are how do you think about that? And then the second question is on the guidance. What kind of -- your hotel revenue has been growing kind of low double-digits that teams towards the end of the year. What kind of revenue growth for hotel baked into the 2011 guidance and can you just talk about some of the trends in international versus domestic on the guidance for hotel?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: On your first question on TripAdvisor, our full year OIBA margin for TripAdvisor was over 53 percent. And it's actually interesting to note that TripAdvisor actually expanded its OIBA margins since 2008 well both growing its business and investing pretty
componenttext: On your first question on TripAdvisor, our full year OIBA margin for TripAdvisor was over 53 percent. And it's actually interesting to note that TripAdvisor actually expanded its OIBA margins since 2008 well both growing its business and investing pretty significantly. That said, in Q4, the OIBA margin big drop. I talked about the same level as the drop that occurred in Q3. Q4 '09 was eight particularly tough comp. That's when the business really started rebounding postrecession. And so we don't really attribute the decline in margin to very much to what's going on with Google, and really, it's more of a reflection of Q4 being seasonally lowest revenue quarter for TripAdvisor and the investments that we're making. As we look forward into 2011, we continue to expect a strong topline. I think Dara talked about click growth in the mid-20%. We're seeing growth in revenue from new products et cetera, but we're going to continue to make the investments in SniqueAway, vacation rentals, China, mobile, social, et cetera, and those things will impact OIBA margins, and we expect probably 700 basis points of drop in 2011 to somewhere around 50% level. In terms of the cost levers for TripAdvisor, there are certain investments that I'd mentioned earlier that we're making that we could perhaps, pull back on if the business grew slower. But we really believe in the long-term potential of those investments. And when you have a business that's as strong as TripAdvisor, that's grown as consistently and profitably as TripAdvisor, the last thing that we're going to start to do is prune back on really good investment opportunities because of a near-term situation where we're adjusting to some lower SEO traffic from Google.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the second question, and that was on guidance and hotel, we are assuming healthy unit growth in our guidance for hotel in 2011. We expect supplier margins to be -- continue to be relatively stable. So that obviously implies good growth in our hotel
componenttext: So on the second question, and that was on guidance and hotel, we are assuming healthy unit growth in our guidance for hotel in 2011. We expect supplier margins to be -- continue to be relatively stable. So that obviously implies good growth in our hotel revenue business in 2011. As between domestic and international, we expect to see the domestic market continue to perform nicely for us, welcome rewards at Hotels.com is very strong in the U.S. Expedia is doing nicely in the U.S. as well. So we expect to continue to grow in the U.S. and take share. In international markets, as we indicated earlier, we're going really hard at Asia and really hard at Latin America. So we expect to see much higher growth rates there, and we already are seeing much higher growth rates. And on Europe, we've really seen a nice rebound at Hotels.com in Europe after the platform work that we did last year. And we're working to get to the same spot with Expedia internationally. So putting it all together, we feel good about the hotel business and its growth prospects for 2011.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung from Deutsche Bank Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Herman Leung from Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, I guess you talked about how TripAdvisors, 50% of revenues but yet, it's only 25% of U.S. IP traffic. Obviously, the U.S. market is very important from a monetization standpoint. And not to be the dead horse, but a lot of folks have been talking ab
componenttext: First, I guess you talked about how TripAdvisors, 50% of revenues but yet, it's only 25% of U.S. IP traffic. Obviously, the U.S. market is very important from a monetization standpoint. And not to be the dead horse, but a lot of folks have been talking about Google places, the impact of that. I know you guys have talked about how it hasn't impacted you guys that much. But curious on what you guys are expecting from a U.S. TripAdvisor growth standpoint in 2011? And then second question I have is on your guidance you had talked about a mid-single-digit kind of an investment growth and obviously, that's going to be more front-end loaded from an investment standpoint. Curious if you can kind of make down between the cost that you're spending on the core business versus the TripAdvisor business and kind of two or three kind of key investment areas there and then I have one very quick follow-up.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Herman, I'll start with Trip, and just what I'd say is we expect -- we are not going to get specific but healthy growth both in the U.S. and internationally as well. Overall, TripAdvisor's unique users, I think that you've got 40 million new use, up
componenttext: Sure. Herman, I'll start with Trip, and just what I'd say is we expect -- we are not going to get specific but healthy growth both in the U.S. and internationally as well. Overall, TripAdvisor's unique users, I think that you've got 40 million new use, up 60% over the beginning of the year. I mean just traffic both in the U.S. and international are growing very fast. We're going to see healthy growth in the U.S. buy one get more specific than that. And international growth will be well in excess of that. The note I will make for TripAdvisor again is that, the fastest-growing part of TripAdvisor international will monetize that a lower rates, but as that monetization, approaches the monetization of the U.S., which over the long term, it should, we expect to see really great things. And then Mike, you want to talk about the investments?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as I understood the question, it's really how much of the investments are core business versus TripAdvisor. And I would say, we've really been investing heavily in TripAdvisor for several years, and we've see nice returns on for example, the busi
componenttext: Sure. So as I understood the question, it's really how much of the investments are core business versus TripAdvisor. And I would say, we've really been investing heavily in TripAdvisor for several years, and we've see nice returns on for example, the business listings investment. There is some increase in that this year but I would say the main increase in investment this year, really is on Expedia. It's the platform work that we've been discussing during the call. It is really the expansion of Expedia into APAC and Latin America, particularly APAC, where we feel like we are underrepresented. We're also investing in a loyalty platform on Expedia. We've seen the great success that Hotels.com has had with its Welcome Rewards loyalty platform. And so we look that bad and sad the way. Is to build it ourselves. So we're doing that, and that takes time. It takes effort, and it takes some investment. But we're really confident but we're confident that we know how to crack these types of nuts.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: So on ADR, we really haven't seen much difference in early January than we saw in Q4. And we saw ADRs up modestly in the U.S. And probably, trailing a bit in internationally.

componenttext: Europe, ADRs in dollar terms, it's flattish. While the U.S. is up low-single digits, and we expect to see -- I would guess more or the same, it's in January, although I think some ADR growth for the industry is certainly going to be healthy.

componenttext: I think you kind of answer when you think about there you're going to put the large focus internationally in 2011, it sounds like APAC, and then I guess what will be other geographies kind of following APAC?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think APAC obviously, number-one, China's going to be fairly -- it's a substantial piece of it. Latin America and Brazil are very big, attractive markets are Hotels.com that we're investing in. Again, Expedia will be coming in with a stronger presence i
componenttext: I think APAC obviously, number-one, China's going to be fairly -- it's a substantial piece of it. Latin America and Brazil are very big, attractive markets are Hotels.com that we're investing in. Again, Expedia will be coming in with a stronger presence in Mexico and starting to establish a presence in Brazil as well. And the European markets as well, I don't want to, by any means, downplay Europe. You obviously see the size and the richness of the European market with some of our competition, especially booking.com, and we're seeing really good results out of Hotels.com in Europe. We're introducing the Hotwire Opaque product into Europe as well this year. Expect that as a Q2 event. We think that's a great product that will lend itself to the European consumer who always wants to take money. And then we're going to put considerable effort behind Expedia which has been trailing somewhat in Europe, and we think some have began the Hotels.com play but as far as driving site conversion with some of these re-platforming we're working in Europe just as it has Hotels.com. So those are kind of the plays that we have on hand.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011

componenttext: And then there's a lot of smaller private companies there doing various components or participating in various components or in various verticals that TripAdvisor has some ficus on. componenttext: I mean there's a whole list of, I guess, you could say, like Uptick, Home Away, Kayak, companies like that.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 10, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I put I guess, I put Kayak and Home Away in different categories. Those are the smaller companies but I'd say, they're category leaders. Home Away is a great business in the Vacation Rentals area and Kayak obviously is a big meta-player here. There a
componenttext: Yes, I put I guess, I put Kayak and Home Away in different categories. Those are the smaller companies but I'd say, they're category leaders. Home Away is a great business in the Vacation Rentals area and Kayak obviously is a big meta-player here. There are lots of meta-players in Europe that are very strong. So I think in those categories, TripAdvisor actually is the one who's hopefully nipping their heels and catching up. TripAdvisor's built a really nice vacation rentals product. We bought a company called the Holiday Lettings in the U.K. to establish our market there. And we think other than Home Away, we think we are the only other company that can build this kind of global subscription base in the dictation rentals product. We're the only ones who have the audience and the ability to bring in reviews and etc. into play. And then on the air meta side as far as Kayak goes, we've built a nice air meta-product in TripAdvisor. Honestly the economics of that air product are not nearly as good as the thing that or mix of the hotel product, but it's a product that or consumers like a lot. And it's a product that we used to attract consumers into the TripAdvisor family and then hopefully, upsell them with the hotel product, with the reviews, with forms etc. It's consumers don't search a lot for air product, and we can use that product to kind of upsell them into everything else that TripAdvisor offers. So we have been expanding the breadth of TripAdvisor's products as we expand the size of TripAdvisor's audience and we love what we see. And we'll keep investing in the new products, in business listings, as well as international just because of the opportunities out there.
