headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Expedia First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Thursday, April 28, 2011. At this time, I'
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Expedia First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Thursday, April 28, 2011. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Alan Pickerill, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Expedia, Inc.'s Financial Results Conference Call for the First Quarter ended March 31, 2011. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Michael Adler, our CF
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Expedia, Inc.'s Financial Results Conference Call for the First Quarter ended March 31, 2011. I'm pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Michael Adler, our CFO.
The following discussion, including responses to your question, reflects management's views as of today, April 28, 2011, only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise this information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You will find reconciliations of non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today on our earnings release, which is posted on the company's IR website at expediainc.com/ir. I encourage you to periodically visit our Investor Relations site for important content, including today's earnings release and our updated investor presentation.
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense, and technology and content expense, excludes stock-based compensation. And all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2010.
With that, let me turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. We're pleased to report strong top line growth at Expedia. With revenue grew nice and free cash flow, all growing 50% in what was a very difficult environment in the first quarter. Few things have changed since we last talked to you. We an
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. We're pleased to report strong top line growth at Expedia. With revenue grew nice and free cash flow, all growing 50% in what was a very difficult environment in the first quarter. Few things have changed since we last talked to you. 
We announces plans to spin-off TripAdvisor, the world's leading travel media company into a separately publicly traded company, an event that we think will highlight TripAdvisor's accomplishment and set the stage for growth for many years to come.
We announced the joint venture with AirAsia, which we believe will prove to be a powerful platform to fuel Expedia's Asia Pacific ambitions. We continue to invest in and deliver on our technology platform plans, and we have American Airlines back in our marketplace.
On the financial front, while our top line was quite healthy considering the relatively reduced quality of our air inventory on Expedia, our bottom line was a bit weaker than expected. We saw continued higher average ticket prices challenging Expedia's air volumes, lower customer discounts in the opaque channel, available to both Hotwire and Expedia packages, and higher than expected G&A, due primarily to legal costs and related reserves, the timing of which we just can't control.
Regarding the spin-off. TripAdvisor and the 18 brands that comprise the TripAdvisor Media Group will separate from Expedia, to be led by President and CEO, Steve Kaufer, who was a Co-Founder of TripAdvisor. We think it's the right time and the right direction for both companies, and each company is ready. 
TripAdvisor's unquestioned leader in the travel media space, with more than 15 million unique users in 29 countries in 20 languages. Expedia will move forward as the world's largest online travel agency with leading leisure and corporate brands, operating more than 100 sites across the globe, and driving more than 26 billion in annual travel bookings toward suppliers all over the world.
We believe that moving ahead as two separate companies will allow each to stand on its own, drive it's own growth in technology, vision and culture, and ultimately, create far more value for our shareholders. We intend to maintain a strong relationship between Expedia and TripAdvisor that comes from our shared history and vision to provide the very best travel products and information.
Announcing our intent to spin off TripAdvisor was just the first step in the process, and it won't happen overnight. This will require full approval from the Board of Directors and amount of work. We're working on the required regulatory filings, and expect to file a proxy statement regarding the transaction with the SEC this spring. The final timing of these types of transactions can be difficult to predict with precision, but we're aiming for the spin-off to be completed sometime in the fall.
In the meantime, both businesses are pushing forward on their respective strategies and we don't expect the spin-off to slow us down.
From an operating perspective, TripAdvisor experienced robust growth in its three main revenue categories during the first quarter of 2011, including over 25% growth in the cost per clicks, CPC-based revenue, on 30% growth in click volume, over 10% increase in display advertising revenue, and over 300% growth in other revenue, which includes our new Business Listings product that we're very excited about. 
TripAdvisor is in enviable position of being to deliver 21% Q1 OIBA growth, while at the same time aggressively investing in long-term growth drivers.
We're pushing hard into Asia Pacific as we see excellent opportunities there for long term, sustainable growth. The APAC opportunities immensed with total travel bookings in the region well over $200 billion, with just a fraction of it online. The biggest development there was our announcement to enter into a joint venture with AirAsia. We're contributing certain of our Expedia brand and point-of-sale on technology, while AirAsia's contributing its 22 AirAsia Go travel booking sites, an exclusive third-party distribution rights for the AirAsia content.  We believe that the first of its kind joint venture between an online travel agency and a low-cost carrier, and we're extremely excited about the opportunity to partner with a terrific local travel operator to grow our APAC business.
In addition to the joint venture opportunity, we'll still have our Hotels.com brand with 15 sites in the region. In fact, we just launched Vietnam and Indonesia today, as well as our controlling interest in eLong. TripAdvisor also continues pushing into the regions, so we're well diversified as we look to capitalize on this opportunity.
From a technology investment perspective, one of the most important efforts is to move the Expedia brand from it's old platform onto its new platform. Once completed, it will allow us to innovate at a much faster pace, delivering new products and features to our customers. It's been about 80 days since our last earnings call, and I will tell you that we're on track on this project. We've got key portions of Expedia brand, hotel path on to the new platform, and we've already started innovating on these pages, new info sites, new hotel search results, filters, urgency messaging, a new checkout path and more, will all serve to improve the experience for our customers and in turn, improve our conversion.
The migration of the hotel path should be complete around the end of June, and the air path, by the end of the year.  Work on the packages path and other products will continue into 2012.
During the quarter, we also officially launched the new Expedia customer loyalty program called Expedia Rewards, and are quite happy with the early metrics we've seen there. 
Now I'd been asked by some of our investors, "what gives me confidence that the investment in Expedia technology platform will pay off?" I'd simply point at Hotels.com. We executed on a similar projects in 2009 which we call 1H internally, it was painful operationally and financially near-term. But the Hotels.com team just delivered on the quarter with nearly 40% gross bookings growth, more than tripling last year's growth rates and has continued to show strong growth in April.
While our aggressive investment, spend and technology marketing will continue to put pressure on our margins, we see improving results in Q2 and the balance of the year, both top line and bottom line. We're also encouraged by the performance of several of our key brands, Hotels.com, as I've previously mentioned, is showing continued strength in virtually, every geography. Our Private Label business is hitting on all cylinders, Egencia continues to grow share in the Corporate Travel market, and rumors of an impending doom for TripAdvisor's traffic have proven to be entirely false.
We know we have a ton of work ahead of us but on balance we feel much better now than we did when we last spoke to you. Now Mike is going to cover the details about some of these trends.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dara. From a brand perspective, we saw a healthy revenue growth across most of our brands and geographies, with the notable exception of our Expedia brand. Hotels.com saw both room night growth, and total revenue growth accelerate nicely in Europe
componenttext:
Thanks, Dara. From a brand perspective, we saw a healthy revenue growth across most of our brands and geographies, with the notable exception of our Expedia brand. Hotels.com saw both room night growth, and total revenue growth accelerate nicely in Europe and Asia Pacific. Our WelcomeRewards program continues to do well, and is helping to drive hotel bookings in North America where Hotels.com room night growth accelerated from 14% growth in the fourth quarter, to a very robust 27% in the first quarter.
Hotels.com Global Standalone Hotel business is now larger than that for the Expedia brand and we're certainly glad to see that momentum. And while the Expedia brand grew hotel revenue at rates similar to last quarter, air tickets were down double digits year-over-year.
From a product perspective, hotel room night growth in Q1 was healthy at 15%, and we saw a good growth in both domestic and international. Our ADRs were up 3% for the quarter with 1% growth in revenue per room nights. 
In air, tickets declined by 10% year-over-year, while we saw an 18% increase in revenue per ticket. As we mentioned last quarter, we have accelerated revenue recognition on our merchant air product to the book date, which accounted for roughly 1/3 of the improvement for ticket.
The 13% increase in average ticket prices, as well as some performance based over rides were the other primary contributing factors. We do not expect to see a year-over-year increase in revenue per ticket as we move through the year.
We've also signed a memorandum of understanding with American Airlines, and we're happy to have their tickets back on the sites. On a broad level, we are accessing and plan to access our air and package content via Global Distribution Systems, and continue to believe the GDSs are the most efficient and effective method for airlines to distribute their content to travel agencies. As we mentioned last quarter, we are ramping key investments, and you can see the impact of that in our operating expenses. 
Of the $60 million increase in selling and marketing expense, a little over 40% was for the Expedia brand. Essentially all of which was for international efforts in Europe and APAC.  Hotels.com made up nearly 30% of the total increase, with that spend relatively balanced across regions.
TripAdvisor accounts for over 20% of the increase as it continues to drive volume growth around the world. Tech and content continues to ramp as we scale up the headcount required to complete our strategic technology projects. The head count increases, are concentrated primarily in our centralized IT function, TripAdvisor, Expedia and our Partner Services Group.
Recent tech and content deliverables have included the launch of two new Expedia-branded websites in APAC, the launch of our new Expedia.com Loyalty Program, new mobile applications for both Expedia and Hotels.com, and the launch of Hotwire in the U.K. to name just a few. We're also hard at work innovating on the front end of Hotels.com, moving Expedia onto his new platform and upgrading our supply platform, as well as other back-end systems.
G&A expense was $5 million higher than we expected this quarter, primarily on an increase in legal costs and related reserves. Unfortunately, these expenses can be somewhat unpredictable and lumpy from quarter-to-quarter. I can say however, that we are still expecting G&A to grow at a slower rate than revenue for full-year 2011.
Lastly, as expected, we saw leverage and cost of revenue as we continue to see payoff from prior investments.
From a profitability perspective, operating income before amortization was down 9%. OIBA decline is due in part to the fact that Q1 is seasonally the lightest revenue quarter of the year while the investments we are making are not seasonal. We do expect to see improving top line performance as we move through the year, and our expense comparisons get easier in the second half. So our expectations are for OIBA growth to be stronger in the back half of the year relative to the first half.
As far as our financial expectations are concerned, last quarter, we said we expected OIBA to grow in the mid-single-digit range for full year 2011. With improved air inventory, we feel better about the business, although higher air ticket and oil prices since the last earnings call, present ongoing headwinds for standalone air and packages. 
Net-net, we think we can do at least, as well as we described last quarter if not a little better. As a housekeeping item, please note that these expectations do not contemplate the additional cost we will incur related to the TripAdvisor spinoff.
With that, let's turn to questions. Operator, would you please remind listeners how to ask a question.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Mark Mahaney with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Mark Mahaney with Citi.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: One question on TripAdvisor, and one question on expenses. TripAdvisor, so it doesn't seem like in terms of the revenue growth that you've seen any material impact. It just kind of shows up sometimes in the traffic data. Do you think your growth for TripA
componenttext: One question on TripAdvisor, and one question on expenses. TripAdvisor, so it doesn't seem like in terms of the revenue growth that you've seen any material impact. It just kind of shows up sometimes in the traffic data. Do you think your growth for TripAdvisor in terms of revenue is being negatively impacted by a Google Places now? Is this something you've been able to work around? Do you think your growth would be even higher if it weren't for Google Places? And then just on the investments, when you think about the ramp up in marketing spend, the best evidence for you is that you're going to get that ROI on that marketing spend, is it the hotels' success you had last year, or would you point to something else?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. As far as TA goes, we were definitely impacted by the changes that Google made in Places. Places, they're favoring their own internal content and pushing down kind of the SEO results down the page, often below the fold. And we certainly saw
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. As far as TA goes, we were definitely impacted by the changes that Google made in Places. Places, they're favoring their own internal content and pushing down kind of the SEO results down the page, often below the fold. And we certainly saw an effect on TripAdvisor traffic at the result of that. I think the reason why you're seeing the revenue strength of TripAdvisor is just because of TripAdvisor's incredible diversity and the underlying strength of the business. So I think if Places wasn't around, TripAdvisor would've grown even faster, but we're seeing very, very good results in TripAdvisor coming out of the international markets. The international markets now were a significant majority of TripAdvisor's traffic. There's still less than, well less than 50% of TripAdvisor's revenue, and TripAdvisor's doing great things internationally, launching new sites, investing pretty aggressively in the Asia Pacific regions, and in launching new products that we're quite happy about, such as the Business Listings product. So it hurt us, but I just think that the TripAdvisor management team has addressed it well, and the business is on a good path, so that we are able to show healthy growth despite Google's actions. As far as the evidence on the ROI, the marketing investments, I'd say continued health and hopefully, acceleration on the room night fan on hotel room nights, which is clearly something that we're pushing. And I would say we would want to see a continuance of the revenue acceleration that we saw in the international markets in Q1. International revenue came in at 31% growth, which was significantly higher than what we saw on Q4. And we're certainly happier with those kinds of numbers than the numbers that we saw kind of late last year. So those are certainly two factors that we look at.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ingrid Chung with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ingrid Chung with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I have a couple of questions around the separation. So first, I was wondering if you could give us a little more color on the reasons for the separation? Will you lose some synergies potentially, between Trip and Expedia? And then secondly, logistics o
componenttext: So I have a couple of questions around the separation. So first, I was wondering if you could give us a little more color on the reasons for the separation? Will you lose some synergies potentially, between Trip and Expedia? And then secondly, logistics of the separation, am I correct in assuming that this is going to be a full asset spend, and where is the debt going to reside then?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll answer the last one first. As far as debt goes, we haven't made any final determinations as to where the debt is going to be. We will make sure that both companies are appropriately capitalized. And as you know, our capital position is very str
componenttext: Sure. I'll answer the last one first. As far as debt goes, we haven't made any final determinations as to where the debt is going to be. We will make sure that both companies are appropriately capitalized. And as you know, our capital position is very strong from a cash standpoint, and the debt levels, our debt levels that are very reasonable. So I don't think that frankly, figuring out what the right capitalization levels for each company is going to be that difficult, we have planet to go around. But we haven't made the full determination of exactly how we're going to structure the companies. That will come out, I think once we file our S-4, et cetera, so that's work to be done. As far as the reasons for the spin, I think they're simple. I think as we've kind of restructure our businesses and created global lines of business and global brands, we've found that focus is incredibly important in performance. And we think that this will focus the employees of kind of new Expedia, the transactional employees to drive those businesses and make sure that the investments that we're making on behalf of our shareholders pay off. And I think that it will focus TripAdvisor to keep building on an incredible asset that, that management team has built. I think anytime that you've got employees who feel like their work has a great chance of affecting, not only how their company does, what products they release, but also how their stock price does and how their pocket books are affected, the more direct that action or reaction is, in the better company's deal. And I think this is going to focus the mind for the transactional businesses that we have to make these investments pay off. And I certainly think that the TripAdvisor team, who I think is really proud of the business that they've built, is going to get those go forward as a public company, and I think it's going to motivate them even more than they've been motivated in the past. So I think net-net, it's going to be a great thing. There are certainly some synergies that we'll lose. One synergy that we loved about having TripAdvisor in the family was that we were hedged against media inflation. As you know, marketing is a very significant cost for Expedia, and having TripAdvisor in the family really provided a wonderful hedge against that. Now our shareholders can create that hedge, and I guess they're in the business of allocating capital. So they can make up their mind down, now, we're giving them optionality. And I do think that the businesses have been working together more. You see TripAdvisor for example, now showing up in Expedia info sites, as far as you see TripAdvisor reviews show up there. I think you'll actually see the businesses work more together going forward, and we're going to make sure that we quote those relations in place in the form of contracts, et cetera, that will make that kind of partnership possible. The last thing I'll say is, we've worked together as a team really well. My senior leadership team with Steve Kaufer, senior and leadership team, we're friends, we respect each other. And I do expect that we will be a great partner of theirs, and they'll be a great partner of ours.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Justin Post of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Justin Post of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Dara, can you talk about the marketing spend in the quarter? It was about I think 70% of gross profit growth if you do the ratio. How much of that was directly driving kind of transactions or volumes in the quarter, of whether it'd be for Hotels or Expedi
componenttext: Dara, can you talk about the marketing spend in the quarter? It was about I think 70% of gross profit growth if you do the ratio. How much of that was directly driving kind of transactions or volumes in the quarter, of whether it'd be for Hotels or Expedia? And how do much you think will pay off, was more brand build down the road? And then secondly, maybe you can talk about the currency impact, will that be pretty favorable both to revenues and OIBA, or do you hedge that at all when you look out the next few quarters?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll let Mike take on currency impact. As far as the marketing spend in the quarter, we don't disclose that of exactly what our marketing spend is offline versus online. I'd say that it's a combination. The online spend clearly brings transactional growth
componenttext: I'll let Mike take on currency impact. As far as the marketing spend in the quarter, we don't disclose that of exactly what our marketing spend is offline versus online. I'd say that it's a combination. The online spend clearly brings transactional growth as easily tractable, et cetera. I would say that in certain markets for example, in the Asia Pacific markets we will spend online highly inefficiently. So either that spend will be breakeven, or that spend sometimes will be losing money, as we're building up volumes, as we're bringing in customers, as we're building up a brand inside those market places. So for example, if you look in the Asia Pacific region when you say, marketing spend was 70% of the gross profit growth, I think [ph] the Asia Pacific region marketing spend is probably closer to 100% of gross profit growth if not more. I'm using round numbers, Mike, so you can correct me if I'm wrong. So you have a mix, which is in the Asia Pacific region where we did make money, we were profitable last year, and this year we will be profitable. We are actually taking every dollar that we're making, every gross profit dollar that we're making. We're putting it into the back into the marketing spend, so that's part of what you see. And then you are seeing in general, an increase in online and offline efforts, both at Expedia and Hotels.com, and TripAdvisor on the traffic acquisition front, where we are being aggressive. But we are seeing some good revenue numbers and some hotel room night numbers as a result. Mike, do you want to talk currency?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. On FX, we did see a slight boost in this quarter on the year-on-year weakening in the U.S. dollar and last year, we saw the U.S. dollar begin to strengthen mid-year. So our current rates new hold that will provide a bit of a tailwind for us. We obvi
componenttext: Sure. On FX, we did see a slight boost in this quarter on the year-on-year weakening in the U.S. dollar and last year, we saw the U.S. dollar begin to strengthen mid-year. So our current rates new hold that will provide a bit of a tailwind for us. We obviously can't control it, so we don't count on it. In terms of what we refer to as a book to say, exposure that we have to FX, and that's between book date and stay date, we do hedge that to the extent that there are large movements from one period to another before the booking actually stays. For the most part, we expect to be neutral.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. But do you think it will be helping your OIBA as we look out, or it could -- if it stay where it's at?
componenttext: Okay. But do you think it will be helping your OIBA as we look out, or it could -- if it stay where it's at?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On a year-on-year basis, it wouldn't. At current levels, it would help.
componenttext: On a year-on-year basis, it wouldn't. At current levels, it would help.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Sandler with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ross Sandler with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just two quick questions. First, thanks for breaking out the bookings growth by property. You mentioned if -- going to these new features at Hotels.com, can you help us understand the specific factors that are driving the 39% growth, and why you feel conf
componenttext: Just two quick questions. First, thanks for breaking out the bookings growth by property. You mentioned if -- going to these new features at Hotels.com, can you help us understand the specific factors that are driving the 39% growth, and why you feel confident that you'll see the same kind of growth once the Expedia Hotel business is rebuilt in June? And then second, one more clarification on the split. How are the ad that are showing up on TripAdvisor that come from Expedia's sites accounted for today? Are those cash expenses, or are they just book expenses without a cash component? And once the split goes through, are those going to be cash expenses for Expedia, or is there going to be like an agreement where a certain amount of inventory will be allocated to Expedia?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: To be specific, the features that are actually are enlisted, are features that are now being delivered on the Expedia hotel path, as its being transitioned onto the new technology. Hotels.com has been delivering those kinds of feature sets and more since
componenttext: To be specific, the features that are actually are enlisted, are features that are now being delivered on the Expedia hotel path, as its being transitioned onto the new technology. Hotels.com has been delivering those kinds of feature sets and more since it's been on the new technology that we launched for a longer period of time. Expedia's kind of at the beginning of the path, and Hotels.com, I'd say, is at the beginning to middle of the path. And as far as our confidence here is, I'll just say the stuff that we're launching is not rocket science. There's a lot of testing and learning that goes into this. There's a lot of science that goes into this, where we're able to introduce a new feature, we're able to test it, AB test it with our customers to see what works in and which don't. And based on Hotels.com's experience, we're seeing that a number of these new features that we are launching, better pictures, better filtering capability, more results, faster results, et cetera, are resulting in more -- a higher percentage of our customers who are visiting our site booking, in other words, higher conversion rates. And these conversion rates are pretty broad. They're applicable in the U.S., they're applicable in Europe, they're applicable in Asia Pacific, which is creating better performance essentially for Hotels.com on a worldwide basis. And we see no reason when we look at the Expedia customer, when we look at the Expedia traffic sources, et cetera, we see no reason why the same application of this technology to the Expedia customers won't work. We will be surprised if it doesn't work. It's a risk that we're taking, but we're very confident in one, the patterns that we're seeing based on our experience with Hotels.com, and two, based on the Expedia team's ability to deliver. So it is a risk, and I think the second half for us will start to tell the tail. And I would expect that Expedia's room night volume in the second half of the year like Q3, Q4, should see some improvement from what we've seen in Q1 and hopefully, we'll be able to deliver that for you. Mike, do you want to answer the second question?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Expedia, Hotels.com, and some of our other brands today, acquire traffic from TripAdvisor, and that relationship today is at fair value and that's reflected in our various segment recording. Go forward, the relationship between Expedia, Hotels an
componenttext: Sure. So Expedia, Hotels.com, and some of our other brands today, acquire traffic from TripAdvisor, and that relationship today is at fair value and that's reflected in our various segment recording. Go forward, the relationship between Expedia, Hotels and TripAdvisor would be like with any third party. So it will be a true cash relationship like with any other party.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ross, does that answer your question?
componenttext: Ross, does that answer your question?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. It's a little bit of [ph]  Today, if a banner from an Expedia site shows up on TripAdvisor, there are not really any cash being exchanged because you're part of the same company.
componenttext: Well, yes. It's a little bit of [ph]  Today, if a banner from an Expedia site shows up on TripAdvisor, there are not really any cash being exchanged because you're part of the same company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's all intercompany, correct. So whether it happens or not, there's various accounting entries and things which occur but today, all the cash is at the Expedia, Inc. level.
componenttext: It's all intercompany, correct. So whether it happens or not, there's various accounting entries and things which occur but today, all the cash is at the Expedia, Inc. level.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: But we think from a P&L standpoint, Ross, you'll largely see a similar P&L and that market conditions may change between now and then as far as the price of clicks, et cetera. But then we think once the companies are spun off, the cash flows will reflect
componenttext: But we think from a P&L standpoint, Ross, you'll largely see a similar P&L and that market conditions may change between now and then as far as the price of clicks, et cetera. But then we think once the companies are spun off, the cash flows will reflect the P&L, right?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is from the line of Naved Khan with Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Next question is from the line of Naved Khan with Jefferies & Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about how much exposure you have to Japan from a bookings and revenue perspective? And can you break out the impact from Japan, the Middle East and over there in Q1 and what's baked in the guidance?
componenttext: Can you talk about how much exposure you have to Japan from a bookings and revenue perspective? And can you break out the impact from Japan, the Middle East and over there in Q1 and what's baked in the guidance?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we have a relatively small exposure to Japan, and it did not really have much of an impact on our Q1 figures and go forward, we don't expect it to have a material impact on the rest of the year. So it's very, very low single-digits.
componenttext: So we have a relatively small exposure to Japan, and it did not really have much of an impact on our Q1 figures and go forward, we don't expect it to have a material impact on the rest of the year. So it's very, very low single-digits.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then a quick clarification on, I think, some of the metrics that Dara gave out earlier. When you spoke about a 25% growth in CPC and 30% growth in the click volume. Is that a growth in -- is the 25% growth really in the CPC, or is it growth in t
componenttext: Okay, and then a quick clarification on, I think, some of the metrics that Dara gave out earlier. When you spoke about a 25% growth in CPC and 30% growth in the click volume. Is that a growth in -- is the 25% growth really in the CPC, or is it growth in the revenue associated with the CPC?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a 25% growth in revenue coming from the CPC line of business for TripAdvisor on a 30% increase in volume as far as 30% increase in clicks from customers.
componenttext: It's a 25% growth in revenue coming from the CPC line of business for TripAdvisor on a 30% increase in volume as far as 30% increase in clicks from customers.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And can you talk about what kind of increase as you are seeing in the cost for impression on the display side?
componenttext: Got it. And can you talk about what kind of increase as you are seeing in the cost for impression on the display side?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the display side, I'd say our CPMs have historically been quite healthy, and we're essentially seeing stable CPMs. I don't think we're seeing very significant increases either up or down. I think TripAdvisor and Expedia, where we have the greatest port
componenttext: On the display side, I'd say our CPMs have historically been quite healthy, and we're essentially seeing stable CPMs. I don't think we're seeing very significant increases either up or down. I think TripAdvisor and Expedia, where we have the greatest portion of the CPM business, have the ability to -- have always have the ability to charge premium prices, because we are really the premium sites that people come to, obviously. TripAdvisor has the greatest amount of traffic, and Expedia is a close second, so we're seeing pretty good stability from CPM results both on the TripAdvisor and Expedia sites as far as rates go.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry.[Canaccord Genuity]
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Heath Terry.[Canaccord Genuity]

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just give us a bit of a sense of where you feel like the European hotel business is trending right now between the agency and merchant model. Obviously, you're evolving your model there. The hotels are beginning to become -- i
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just give us a bit of a sense of where you feel like the European hotel business is trending right now between the agency and merchant model. Obviously, you're evolving your model there. The hotels are beginning to become -- it seems like more accepting of both models. Could you give us just a bit of an update of where you see that environment?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- honestly, Heath, we're fairly neutral on it. When we talk about our business, we're not in the business of selling merchant hotels. We are in the business of selling hotels. And we bought Venere a few years back in order to make sure that
componenttext: Yes, I think -- honestly, Heath, we're fairly neutral on it. When we talk about our business, we're not in the business of selling merchant hotels. We are in the business of selling hotels. And we bought Venere a few years back in order to make sure that we have access to the agency hotel model, to understand that model, and also because we thought Venere was a good brand. And being marketers of hotels, we're essentially neutral. We want to be able to sign up a high number of hotels in the European marketplace to the extent that hotels are smaller hotels, et cetera. Independent hotels often we'll sign them up as agency hotels and market them as such, to the extent that their larger hotels that want to participate in the Package business, we'll sign them up as merchant hotels and we'll market them as such. So I think that the strength that we're seeing in Europe isn't particularly because of merchant versus agency. It's because we're marketing our brands a bit more effectively, and some of the technology investments that we're making are resulting in conversion increases that helped both merchant and agency volumes in Europe, both of which are growing.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we are seeing increased growth in smaller markets in Europe for agency. It's where it's having its biggest impact.
componenttext: And we are seeing increased growth in smaller markets in Europe for agency. It's where it's having its biggest impact.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, to Mike's points, the growth rates in Europe, tend to be fastest in the secondary and tertiary markets, where we are able to add agency inventory in addition to merchant inventory.
componenttext: Yes, to Mike's points, the growth rates in Europe, tend to be fastest in the secondary and tertiary markets, where we are able to add agency inventory in addition to merchant inventory.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And to your point on conversion rates, that obviously, implies that all that search engines are having in Europe, do you see an opportunity there to make brand more important in that market? Or is the hotel business just going to be beholden to whoever ki
componenttext: And to your point on conversion rates, that obviously, implies that all that search engines are having in Europe, do you see an opportunity there to make brand more important in that market? Or is the hotel business just going to be beholden to whoever kind of has the best conversion rates and able to bid the highest?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think that one of the strengths of our business is that we have a mix of brand and variable marketing, and that's part of our core strategy. Obviously, we've got some competitors who were very strong on brand, and we've got some competitors who go e
componenttext: No. I think that one of the strengths of our business is that we have a mix of brand and variable marketing, and that's part of our core strategy. Obviously, we've got some competitors who were very strong on brand, and we've got some competitors who go exclusively with variable marketing. Conversion will help both, right? If you've got higher conversion that allows you to afford to spend more in variable marketing channels to acquire more volume in the variable marketing channels, but it also theoretically helps you invest more in brand or invest more profitably in brand marketing. So we don't view the kind of goals of increasing conversion as being either an online or offline strategy, it's just a business strategy.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Scott Kessler with Standard & Poor's.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Scott Kessler with Standard & Poor's.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you guys could talk a little bit about the business segment, specifically obviously, Egencia. What's been driving the growth there? What kind of trends are you seeing? Is it fair to assume that the recovery in business travel is underwa
componenttext: I was wondering if you guys could talk a little bit about the business segment, specifically obviously, Egencia. What's been driving the growth there? What kind of trends are you seeing? Is it fair to assume that the recovery in business travel is underway?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say it's definitely fair to say that the recovery in business travel is underway. There are three factors that are driving Egencia's growth. One is new client signings in excess of any client churn, and the signing volume for the business remains
componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's definitely fair to say that the recovery in business travel is underway. There are three factors that are driving Egencia's growth. One is new client signings in excess of any client churn, and the signing volume for the business remains healthy. I'd say on balance, Europe is a real area of strength for us where we have terrific, terrific momentum in France, where we have a very strong position. The U.K. is turning out to be a nice market as well, and then obviously, the U.S. is a great base market as well. So client signings is one driver. The second driver is that same client spend is up as well, as just companies that cut back in travels spend our traveling again, they're hitting the road again in order to drive sales. And the third factor is that, that the price of travel in general is up. I think you saw our average ATPs, systemwide were up 13%. That's true generally for the leisure and the business travel as well. So the cost of travel has gone up, and we haven't yet seen the cost of travel kind of discouraged businesses from traveling, although that's something that we're going to be watching pretty closely. So I'd say pretty solid trends there. Egencia's growth bookings grew 36% in Q1, compared to American Express at 17% in American Express Corporate Travel. So we're gaining share there, and the team is executing well, so we like what we see there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And if I could follow up really quickly, do you feel like you have the scale, or at least have the scale at hand to be able to compete in the way that you want? Or do you think it makes sense to consider acquisitions or broader partnerships, or things lik
componenttext: And if I could follow up really quickly, do you feel like you have the scale, or at least have the scale at hand to be able to compete in the way that you want? Or do you think it makes sense to consider acquisitions or broader partnerships, or things like that? How do you think abut the business a couple of years from now, for example?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. Listen, I think we're finally at the point where we have profitable scale on the business, and that's important for us. We spent six years basically putting every revenue dollar back into the business, and then you saw the business scale prett
componenttext: Sure, sure. Listen, I think we're finally at the point where we have profitable scale on the business, and that's important for us. We spent six years basically putting every revenue dollar back into the business, and then you saw the business scale pretty dramatically last year. And we're at the point now where we can grow the business profitably for some period of time, at the same time, making very aggressive investments in new technology, et cetera, making investments in our sales force as well. That said, we are going to try to act at the scale of business. One example is the Travelforce acquisition. It was the smallest yield that we announced in early April, in Australia and New Zealand. We will look to bring in new a corporate travel agencies into the fold. We will look to integrate them into the Egencia technology, which we think is a market-leading technology at lower cost, and also it has able to leverage off of some of the technology and the supply that we've got at greater Expedia. So we think we have the scale, but we actually think that through talk and acquisitions, we can scale this business a whole lot more. So we're certainly on the lookout for acquisitions as well as organic growth.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Michael Millman with Millman Research Associates.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Regarding the platform, it doesn't seem like Priceline has any particular, a very sophisticated platform to do very well. What's the difference between the two businesses? And also, could you quantify what added conversion may mean to revenue as bottom li
componenttext: Regarding the platform, it doesn't seem like Priceline has any particular, a very sophisticated platform to do very well. What's the difference between the two businesses? And also, could you quantify what added conversion may mean to revenue as bottom line? And unrelated to that, in the Japanese supply chain problems causing some fleet contractions in car rental, and so what effects are you seeing on your availability there? And to what extent are they moving away from you -- or the current company is moving away from having you as OTAs?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll start with the first question. It's difficult to speculate on Priceline and their technology. But I would say that certainly, the Booking.com business for them that has been extraordinarily successful, was we believe built on kind of call it, n
componenttext: Sure, I'll start with the first question. It's difficult to speculate on Priceline and their technology. But I would say that certainly, the Booking.com business for them that has been extraordinarily successful, was we believe built on kind of call it, newer technology than ours which is 10, 15 years old or some of it, but the base of it is. You'll also noticed that the hotel business had shift a lot easier and simpler to architect than the Air, Hotel, Packages business. So you'll notice that as far as the platform investments that we made, the first release that we made was Hotels.com, and that was not a multiyear project. It was a little bit more than a year and from start to end. And as far as the payoff, and what you think the payoff is, I just again, I point to Hotels.com on a worldwide basis, gross bookings growth of 39% on the hotel side in Q1, versus 12% last year. Are we going to see that kind of multiplier effect on Expedia after the fact that's certainly I'm not counting on it, but an accelerator on Expedia would be, would result in great, great top line and bottom line results for the company as a whole, and that's what we're betting on. The Expedia platform in addition to just being air, hotel, packages, et cetera, is also a worldwide platform, so it's complex, it's incredibly capable. And the good news is that we've finally feel like we wrestled it down, and it's just a question of execution. It's not a question of if we can do it or what the architecture is looking like. The team is on top of it and executing, and I think that if we see similar results in Hotels.com, we'll be over the moon. Mike, do you want to talk about car bet?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, so on the car side of the business, we did see transaction growth this quarter. We grew both at Expedia and at Hotwire, and we did see an increase there for in -- in gross bookings, and we did have a bit of pressure on the pricing side. We are getti
componenttext: Sure, so on the car side of the business, we did see transaction growth this quarter. We grew both at Expedia and at Hotwire, and we did see an increase there for in -- in gross bookings, and we did have a bit of pressure on the pricing side. We are getting less access to opaque inventory. So we are selling more or distributing more on the retail side of the business. In terms of what's happening in the supply chain, we definitely are seeing tightening up on summer fleets. We expect demands to be stronger and yes, some fleet shortages this summer. So that will be a headwind for our business, particularly on the opaque side of the house. And in terms of -- do the car rental companies want to continue to work with OTAs, they definitely want to continue to work with us, and we're very happy about that and in fact, just renewed our deal with enterprise.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think in general, the value that we bring to a number of these players and it's not unique to car rental companies is the demand allows them to increase the yields on the full book of business that they do with us. So to the extent that they lose t
componenttext: Yes. I think in general, the value that we bring to a number of these players and it's not unique to car rental companies is the demand allows them to increase the yields on the full book of business that they do with us. So to the extent that they lose the demand from us, then the full book of business might get weaker, in which can hurt revenue. And I think the broader set of healthy channels that you have as any kind of retailer, the stronger you can do yielding your inventory, and I think especially in a situation coming up for the car rental companies, where inventory is going to be tighter. We think having more demand and strengthening yield is a good thing for everybody.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you just give us a rough approximation of the quantification of better conversion to the top line?
componenttext: Could you just give us a rough approximation of the quantification of better conversion to the top line?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, it depends on what conversion is, right? So if you increase your conversion by 5%, we should be 5% higher top line. Although you will, at times, see a multiplier of that, because the 5% increase in top line typically allows you to invest, flip in m
componenttext: Again, it depends on what conversion is, right? So if you increase your conversion by 5%, we should be 5% higher top line. Although you will, at times, see a multiplier of that, because the 5% increase in top line typically allows you to invest, flip in more variable marketing channels. So a 5% increase in conversion will actually result in a higher increase in top line as a result of -- depending on what variable marketing channels you have available to you. But there's no kind of call it, easy one-to-one relationship there.

componenttext: Can you talk about American and all, and I guess is no, but I wanted to see if you could talk about the change in economics and maybe when the GDS last direct connect will be implemented?

componenttext: You guessed it right, Kevin. We're happy to have them in the marketplace, and other than that, we can't comment. componenttext: No timing yet. We're working on particulars and if we have something to announce, we'll certainly announced it.

componenttext: Okay. And I guess in terms of like who might have call who, American is still participating with Orbitz, so can we read that as maybe you guys calling them?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: My mother actually called them. No. Kevin, again, I don't want to get into specifics. I think that it is in our interest to carry full inventory. It's an airlines interest to have as broad distribution as we can have. So broadly, I think to the extent we
componenttext: My mother actually called them. No. Kevin, again, I don't want to get into specifics. I think that it is in our interest to carry full inventory. It's an airlines interest to have as broad distribution as we can have. So broadly, I think to the extent we can come to terms with each other. We can all make more money, especially in this environment with higher fuel prices, et cetera. So other than that, I won't make a comment. I think, listen, I don't this is a deal where either party can declare a victory. I think it was a fair deal and hopefully, it can lead to bigger and better things.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have two question please. One is, Dara, Google find the good approval for the ITA software acquisition. Are you comfortable with the conditions provided by the regulators? And what can you do stand in your competitive positioning? And on a separate topi
componenttext: I have two question please. One is, Dara, Google find the good approval for the ITA software acquisition. Are you comfortable with the conditions provided by the regulators? And what can you do stand in your competitive positioning? And on a separate topic, can you give us any early examples or sign of traction for how your measurement -- you been making technology Asia Pacific and TripAdvisor are now being involve?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, as far as Google ITA goes, we don't have the detail of exactly what the conditions mean. We think that the Justice Department taking a position that the merger needed conditions in order to go forward, we think that's an appropriate position, and we
componenttext: Sure, as far as Google ITA goes, we don't have the detail of exactly what the conditions mean. We think that the Justice Department taking a position that the merger needed conditions in order to go forward, we think that's an appropriate position, and we agree with that. And obviously, we're interested in Google's kind of go forward action, and whether the Justice Department, or the FDC, or the EU looks into their action and into their actions and kind of their general market power. So we don't think that this is the end of the story, and we'll be an interested participants, and at the same time, we're partnered with Google, and we expect to take advantage of the new products that they deliver and we're aggressive advertisers in their marketplaces. As far as their new products that we expect from them, Places, et cetera, I think things haven't changed really. Google is an advertiser, and to the extent that we've got great brands and great inventory and a site that converts, we'll be able to bid aggressively and competitively on the leads that they send us. So more leads from Google is a good thing, and we think we'll be getting more leads from Google for sometime to come. As far as the investments in Asia Pacific products, et cetera, I'd say you will see it in the international numbers over time. Asia Pacific is still a relatively small portion of our business. But it is -- we're at a position now when we're slightly profitable, essentially breakeven. And our interests right now is to grow the platform in the Asia Pacific market. It's as we are building up revenue to reinvest that revenue in marketing, reinvest that revenue back into technology, et cetera. We think that the joint venture with AirAsia is a terrific platform to grow off of, and we're seeing really, really good results out of both TripAdvisor and Hotels.com in the Asia Pacific region. And we will try to give you a little nuggets of information, et cetera, but right now, I'd say that the international health that you see on the revenue side, it's certainly partially due to efforts that we're making in the Asia Pacific region. And last but not the least, we're very, very happy with the strides that eLong has made in China. We've got a great management team in place there, laser-focused on the hotel market there. Their laser-focused on online hotel, driving the Online Hotel business, and we're seeing very healthy room night growth and I think we'll see that for sometime to come.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Bill Lennon with Monest Crest Bigheart [ph]
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Bill Lennon with Monest Crest Bigheart [ph]

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to ask 3 and I'll try to make it as quickly as possible. Number one, you've brought in a lot of head count to work on the hotels and Expedia platforms. And let's say, I don't know if they'll ever be done, and done is in quotations marks, but let's
componenttext: I want to ask 3 and I'll try to make it as quickly as possible. Number one, you've brought in a lot of head count to work on the hotels and Expedia platforms. And let's say, I don't know if they'll ever be done, and done is in quotations marks, but let's say when these efforts are largely done to complete you're 90% of where you want to be, what happens to all the headcount you brought on specifically for these projects? That's number one. Number two, with respect to Asia Pacific being aggressive in the region, I think you said, "we look at hotels signings in the top 10 AP leisure destinations during the quarter," and it looks like the Priceline brands increase their hotels signings by more than 50% sequentially in fact, past Expedia for the top number 1 spot. Expedia signings would likely go up at about 7% by comparison. So do you think you're being -- although you characterize your effort in Asia as aggressive, do you think you're being as aggressive as you need to be given how aggressive the Priceline family is? And third question, any feedback from hotels on Google Places, the efficacy of it? As a traveler and this is anecdotal, I look at it, it doesn't seem very helpful to me, so I'm wondering if your hotels have given you any feedback on the product.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as headcount goes, it's a great question. We're actually careful to bring in the effort that's needed to build out these platforms is a fixed headcount internal employees and also, variable headcount as well. And so like you said, to the exten
componenttext: Yes. As far as headcount goes, it's a great question. We're actually careful to bring in the effort that's needed to build out these platforms is a fixed headcount internal employees and also, variable headcount as well. And so like you said, to the extent that you're going to have a significant increase in throughput needed to build up this platform, we don't want to bring all of this throughput, a 100% on the throughput in-house, because what do we do with those folks once the work is done? So because we're bringing in some of that throughput through variable headcount, we should be able to, to the extent that we don't find other projects for this folk to do, we should be able to take down the variable headcount and kind of get into a more normal mode of operation. And also, I agree with you, you're never done with these kinds of things. I would say that, with the new platform that we are building is fundamentally architected in a different way from the older platform, it's much more of a service-oriented architecture. It's much more flexible, et cetera. So I would hope that we don't have to go through the kind of the fundamental rearchitecting, as well as the rebuilding of the platform that we're going through now in the future. We're strongly architecting it so that we don't have to go through this again. At the same time, we will have to have a certain percentage of our throughput working on the platform improving it so that we don't get into this situation again. As far as the APAC supply, we are -- last year, we increased our supply on a worldwide basis very, very aggressively. And one thing that we did say is that we would focused more on building out demand into the base of hotels that we have. This is both in Europe and in the Asia Pacific markets. In general, our supply in the Asia Pacific market has been growing nicely, it's over 30%. And we are sending volume into these hotels, which is very, very important. Is it aggressive enough, et cetera? I think sometimes, with the opportunity in that market, you never feel like it's aggressive enough. And we certainly feel the competition from not just Priceline and Agoda, but a lot of the local players out there, the free trips of the world, the wonders of the world. But it's such a large market that we don't think it's a winner-take-all market. We think there'll be 3, 4, 5, or 6 players who are solidly profitable. And we think we've built the platform where we can be one of those players as well. Lastly, on places, we really haven't had that much feedback from hotels on Google Places. I shared with you that the products I think can improve a lot, but Google is a great consumer product company, and I would expect them to improve it. And I think the challenge for us, for the TripAdvisor team, et cetera, is to make sure that our specialized vertical products stay ahead of, call it, their more generalized product. And I think that's certainly something that we're up for.
